prior_works.title: A Contextual-Bandit Approach to Personalized News Article Recommendation
prior_works.authors: Lihong Li, Wei Chu, John Langford, Robert E. Schapire
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the LinUCB paradigm for linear contextual bandits, which poLinUCB directly extends by incorporating post-serving contexts into confidence-based action selection and estimation.

prior_works.title: Contextual Bandits with Linear Payoff Functions
prior_works.authors: Wei Chu, Lihong Li, Lev Reyzin, Robert E. Schapire
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided formal analysis and regret bounds for linear contextual bandits using confidence ellipsoids, supplying the analytical template that poLinUCB adapts to exploit post-serving contexts.

prior_works.title: Improved Algorithms for Linear Stochastic Bandits
prior_works.authors: Yasin Abbasi-Yadkori, Dávid Pál, Csaba Szepesvári
prior_works.role: Core analysis tool (OFUL, self-normalized bounds, EPL)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed the self-normalized martingale inequality and confidence-set analysis (including the Elliptical Potential Lemma) that poLinUCB robustifies to handle noise introduced by post-serving contexts.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Linear Optimization under Bandit Feedback
prior_works.authors: Anupam Dani, Thomas Hayes, Sham Kakade
prior_works.role: Early linear bandit analysis and potential argument
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established foundational potential-based analyses for linear bandits; poLinUCB’s generalized Elliptical Potential Lemma builds on this line by extending potential arguments to noisy, augmented data.

prior_works.title: Online Learning under Delayed Feedback
prior_works.authors: Pooya Joulani, András György, Csaba Szepesvári
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formalized learning with information arriving after actions, influencing the modeling of post-serving contexts and the design of updates that incorporate post-action signals without breaking regret guarantees.

prior_works.title: From Bandits to Experts: On the Value of Side-Observations
prior_works.role: Conceptual basis for leveraging auxiliary observations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how side observations can accelerate learning; poLinUCB leverages post-serving contexts as a structured side observation to shrink uncertainty faster than standard contextual bandits.

prior_works.title: Bandits with Feedback Graphs
prior_works.authors: Noga Alon, Nicolò Cesa-Bianchi, Ofer Dekel, Tomer Koren
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a formalism for exploiting structured feedback revealed after actions; this perspective underpins treating post-serving contexts as additional, structure-induced information in updates and analysis.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—poLinUCB and its tight regret guarantees in the presence of post-serving contexts—sits squarely on the linear contextual bandit lineage and the confidence-set analysis it enabled. LinUCB (Li et al., 2010) and its formal treatment in Chu et al. (2011) supply the algorithmic scaffold: choose actions via optimistic linear predictions with uncertainty quantified by confidence ellipsoids. The regret analysis tools of Abbasi-Yadkori et al. (2011) and Dani et al. (2008), especially the self-normalized bounds and the Elliptical Potential Lemma, are the analytical backbone; this work’s core technical advance is to robustify and generalize those lemmas to accommodate noisy, augmented data streams created by post-serving contexts. Conceptually, the model is motivated by settings where information arrives after an action, echoing the delayed-feedback paradigm (Joulani et al., 2013) and the broader idea that auxiliary signals can accelerate learning. Mannor and Shamir (2011) crystallized the value of side observations, and Alon et al. (2015) formalized how post-action feedback structure can be exploited; both perspectives guide treating post-serving contexts as additional, structured observations that shrink uncertainty faster. Together, these works directly inform both the design of poLinUCB—an optimistic linear method augmented with post-action features—and the paper’s main analytical innovation: a noise-tolerant, generalized Elliptical Potential Lemma yielding tight regret despite the new post-serving information channel.
